BodyCopy.p: Most captives were probably unaware that InsureTech hosted its first annual conference October 5–6, 2016, in Las Vegas. The first InsureTech Connect 2016 conference had an estimated 1,500 attendees. From around the world, tech entrepreneurs, investors, and insurance executives met to discuss the impact of technology on the future of the insurance industry.
Andrew Simpson attended the event and filed a report, “10 Takeaways from the Future of Insurance and InsureTech Connect Conference,” for the Insurance Journal on October 17, 2016.

“What follows are some impressions from the busy two-day conference. These in no way reflect all of the ideas or themes at the conference—only those from sessions I attended and people I cornered. I haven’t yet figured out how to be in more than one place at a time, although I would not be surprised if there is a technology to allow that,” Mr. Simpson writes in the article.
The following are Mr. Simpson’s 10 takeaways from the conference.

ul.li: Agents and brokers, although facing significant disruptions to their business model, will survive. Smart agents/brokers will migrate to areas where they can add real value, for instance, large commercial risks.

The most disruptive players in property/casualty, such as the peer-to-peer (P2P) company Lemonade, may be what are known as “full stack” companies. These companies are interested in replacing the existing legacy insurers with new business models instead of building upon systems that are already in place.
While P2P models are interesting, they are unlikely to be a large player in the evolving market.
Traditional insurers are very active in the InsureTech scene.
InsureTech will prosper because the current insurance industry is over-expensed, marred by inefficiencies and inadequate use of data, according to Brian Duperreault, CEO of Hamilton Insurance Group.
Behavioral science will significantly impact the way insurers interact with clients, particularly in personal lines.
Telematics will be important, especially as they migrate into commercial auto.
Companies must embrace change and build trust.
The use of third-party data to improve underwriting and claims will add value, as the “big data” juggernaut will continue.
Companies need to become more “customer” focused and design products that meet their needs.
